SharpNEAT looks like it's starting to work really well, and the 
simulations are great.  What is the fitness function being used in 
the no wiggle pole balancing?  Is it the Gruau one used in our 
paper?  Because the fitness numbers I'm seeing don't look familiar 
to me in that experiment.

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Colin Green <cgreen@d...> wrote:
> I wasn't intending to put out another release just yet as I am in 
the 
> middle of a code reorganisation. However I though some might like 
to see 
> the various improvements as they stand today...
> 
>  - Marked improvement on single-pole search. In fact it's quite 
normal 
> to see perfect solutions within the initial population! This is 
mainly 
> due to using fully connected networks in the initial population. I 
> discussed this with Ken and this is was also seen in his 
experiment's. 
> The connection weight mutation has also been refined.
> 
>  - New double-pole-balancing and double-pole-without-velocity-
input 
> experiments.
> 
>  - Updated the pole balancing simulator to show force acting on 
cart and 
> support double-pole experiment.
> 
> Zipped source code and .Net binaries here: 
http://www.cgreen.dsl.pipex.com/
> 
> One thing I'm just playing with now is an alternative fitness 
scheme to 
> prevent the double-pole-without-velocity problem being solved by 
quickly 
> wiggling the poles, as described in "Efficient Reinforcement 
Learning 
> through Evolving Neural Network Topologies" (Ken and Risto 
> Miikkulainen). This is in the released code/binaries but I haven't 
had 
> chance to experiment with this yet, I did a quick run and it still 
> evolved 'wiggling' solutions.
> 
> Regards,
> 
> Colin
